solution:
Putting our logarithm into exponential notation gives $(x-1)^2=10-2x$. Expanding, we have

\begin{align*}
x^2-2x+1&=10-2x\\
\Rightarrow\qquad x^2+1&=10\\
\Rightarrow\qquad x^2&=9\\
\Rightarrow\qquad x&=\pm 3.\\
\end{align*}However, $x=-3$ does not work, because then the base of the logarithm would be $x-1=-3-1=-4$, and the base of a logarithm can't be negative. So our only solution is $x=\boxed{3}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Raise $\log_{x-1}(10-2x)$ to the power of 10 to get rid of the logarithm.
Step 2: To clear the logarithm, we raise both sides of the equation to the power of 10.

$\left(\log_{x-1}(10-2x)\right)^{10}=2^{10}$
Step 3: $\left(x-1\right)^{20}=\left(10-2x\right)^{10}$
Step 4: Expand both sides using the binomial theorem and combine like terms.
$\left(x-1\right)^{20}=\left(10-2x\right)^{10}$
Step 5: $\left(x^{20}-20x^{19}+\cdots+1\right)=\left(10^{10}-2^{10}\cdot 10^{n}x+\cdots\right)$
Step 6: Equate the coefficients of the corresponding terms on both sides of the equation, in particular the terms involving $x^{19}$ and the constant terms.
$\left(-20x^{19}+\cdots\right)=\left(-2^{10}\cdot 10^{n}x+\cdots\right)$
Step 7: Equate the coefficients of the corresponding terms on both sides of the equation, in particular the terms involving $x^{19}$ and the constant terms.
$-20=-(2^{10})(10^{n})$
Step 8: Simplify the equation to find the value of $n$.
$-20=-(2^{10})(10^{n})$
$20=2^{10}10^{n}$
$2^{10}10^{n}=2^{3}5^{2}$
$10^{n}=2^{3-10}5^{2}$
$10^{n}=\frac{5^{2}}{2^{7}}$
Step 9: 
$10^{n}=\frac{5^{2}}{2^{7}}$
$10^{n}=\frac{25}{128}$
